description.narrative: The project seeks to achieve amongst other objectives to Strengthening Capacity and Coordination as well as ensure accountability and transparency in humanitarian activities in Plateau and Nassarawa State respectively. This is because there are gaps especially atthe state level and across the states on how disasters are managed, and lapses in coordination when disaster occurs. It is envisagethat the project activities in these states in the North Central will further strengthen the capacity of the actors/stakeholder to mitigate and coordinate effectively whenever there is a disaster in the future. This will be done by providing a framework for the Humanitarian Actors of Plateau and Nassarawa states and other responding agencies and organizations to work together to accomplish the following objectives: # Review and development of contingency plans in Plateau and Nassarawa State # Assist the states with capacity building on disaster preparedness and response capabilities. # Promote and enhance the capacity of the government to respond tocomplex humanitarian emergencies. # Assist in developing a coordinated response culture to disasters and other hazards. # Establishment of Humanitarian forum in the project location for information sharing learning and coordination # Enshrined transparency and accountability in humanitarian actions in the states

participating-org.narrative:
Emergency Preparedness and Response Team (EPRT) is a network of over 11 collaborating Organizations (comprising of NGOs, FBOs and two Government Organizations) balanced by faith and gender. These organizations are as follows: - Jama#atul Nasril Islam (JNI), Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), Country Women Association of Nigeria (COWAN), Federation of Muslim Women Associations in Nigeria (FOMWAN), Centre for Peace Advancement in Nigeria (CEPAN), Nigerian Red Cross Society (NRCS), Mennonite Central Committee (MCC), National Council of Muslim Youth Organizations in Nigeria (NACOMYO), Justice Development and Peace/Caritas (JDPC), National OrientationAgency (NOA) and State Emergency Management Authority (SEMA) with 15 members each of the 17 Local Government Areas of Plateau State.
Founded in July, 2005, EPRT was formed to serve as the coordinating body to respond to the needs of victims of natural and man-made disasters in Plateau State. The initial design also incorporated 4 additional States in thecapacity building training namely: - Kano, Kaduna, Bauchi and Benue States. This programme has since 2005 responded to the needs of over 100,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) as well as victims of natural disasters in the state irrespective of creed, religion or tribe. From December 2012 the programme progressed into the formation of Peace Clubs in Secondary Schools under the Catch Them Young Programme as part of our conflict mitigation strategy. We are also running an Early Warning and Early Response a partnership project with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and Operation Rainbow. Although the project is yet to be launched, it is already yielding a lot of progress as a result of the skeletal services rendered by our Data Managers.Under this partnership, registration forms were administered, shortlisted, given leadership training and currently undergoing skills acquisition training (for 150 victims of the violent conflicts in Plateau State (comprising women and youths)
Our activities include: - # Assessment, Registration of IDPs and Relief intervention # Rehabilitation and Re-settlement # Advocacy Visits to Key Religious, Traditional, Community Leaders and Security Personnel # Networking and building strategic partnerships # Capacity Building of Humanitarian Actors # Formation of Peace Clubs in Secondary Schools # Implementing programmes and projects with communities to improve their livelihoods # Monitoring and evaluation of programme activities
